nodes.description: Transaction Management: Transactions are units of work performed on the database.

nodes.title: Normalization
nodes.description: Normalization: Normalization is the process of organizing data in a database to reduce redundancy and dependency.

nodes.title: Approaches for managing large volumes of data
nodes.description: Approaches for managing large volumes of data: e.g., noSQL database systems, use of MapReduce

nodes.label: Data Modeling
nodes.title: Data Modeling
nodes.description: Data Modeling:

nodes.label: Data modeling
nodes.title: Data modeling
nodes.description: Data modeling: Data modeling is the process of defining the structure of a database to represent the data and its relationships in a meaningful way.

nodes.label: Relational data models
nodes.title: Relational data models
nodes.description: Relational data models: Relational data models organize data into tables (relations) consisting of rows (tuples) and columns (attributes).

nodes.label: Conceptual models (e.g., entity‐ relationship, UML diagrams)
nodes.title: Conceptual models (e.g., entity‐ relationship, UML diagrams)
nodes.description: Conceptual models (e.g., entity‐ relationship, UML diagrams): e.g., entity‐ relationship, UML diagrams

nodes.label: Semi‐structured data model
nodes.title: Semi‐structured data model
nodes.description: Semi‐structured data model: expressed using DTD, XML, or JSON Schema, for example

nodes.label: Relational Databases
nodes.title: Relational Databases
nodes.description: Relational Databases: Relational databases store data in tables consisting of rows and columns, with each row representing a record and each column representing an attribute.

nodes.label: Entity and referential integrity
nodes.title: Entity and referential integrity
nodes.description: Entity and referential integrity: Candidate key, superkeys

nodes.label: Relational database design
nodes.title: Relational database design
nodes.description: Relational database design: Relational database design involves identifying entities, attributes, and relationships, and then mapping them to tables, columns, and foreign keys.

nodes.label: Mapping conceptual schema ta relational schema
nodes.title: Mapping conceptual schema ta relational schema
nodes.description: Mapping conceptual schema ta relational schema: Understand the process of translating a conceptual data model into a relational database schema, mapping entities, attributes, and relationships to tables, columns, and foreign keys.

nodes.label: Physical database design: file and storage structures
nodes.title: Physical database design: file and storage structures
nodes.description: Physical database design: file and storage structures: Delve into the physical design aspects of relational databases, including file organization, index structures, and storage optimization techniques to enhance performance and scalability.

nodes.label: Functional dependency Theory
nodes.title: Functional dependency Theory
nodes.description: Functional dependency Theory: Study functional dependencies as a fundamental concept in relational databases, describing the relationships between attributes and ensuring data integrity through normalization.

nodes.label: Normalization Theory
nodes.title: Normalization Theory
nodes.description: Normalization Theory:

nodes.label: Decomposition of a schema; lossless‐join and dependency‐ preservation properties of a decomposition Normal forms (BCNF)
nodes.title: Decomposition of a schema; lossless‐join and dependency‐ preservation properties of a decomposition Normal forms (BCNF)
nodes.description: Decomposition of a schema; lossless‐join and dependency‐ preservation properties of a decomposition Normal forms (BCNF):

nodes.label: Denormalization (for efficiency)
nodes.title: Denormalization (for efficiency)
nodes.description: Denormalization (for efficiency): Denormalization is the process of intentionally introducing redundancy into a database design to improve query performance.

nodes.label: Query Construction
nodes.title: Query Construction
nodes.description: Query Construction: Query construction involves formulating requests to retrieve, manipulate, or analyze data from a database.

nodes.label: SQL Query Formulation
nodes.title: SQL Query Formulation
nodes.description: SQL Query Formulation: SQL queries consist of various clauses such as SELECT, FROM, WHERE, GROUP BY, HAVING, and ORDER BY.

nodes.label: Relational Algebra
nodes.title: Relational Algebra
nodes.description: Relational Algebra: Relational algebra is a theoretical framework for manipulating relational data, describing operations such as selection, projection, union, intersection, and join.

nodes.label: SQL
nodes.title: SQL
nodes.description: SQL: SQL (Structured Query Language) is a standard language used for interacting with relational databases.

nodes.label: Data definition including integrity and other constraints specification
nodes.title: Data definition including integrity and other constraints specification
nodes.description: Data definition including integrity and other constraints specification:

nodes.label: Update sublanguage
nodes.title: Update sublanguage
nodes.description: Update sublanguage: The update sublanguage in SQL includes commands for modifying existing data in the database.

nodes.label: Query Processing
nodes.title: Query Processing
nodes.description: Query Processing: Query processing involves translating a query expressed in SQL or a similar language into a sequence of operations that can be executed by the database system.

nodes.label: Index structures
nodes.title: Index structures
nodes.description: Index structures: Index structures are data structures used to improve the efficiency of data retrieval operations, such as searching and sorting.

nodes.label: B+ trees
nodes.title: B+ trees
nodes.description: B+ trees: B+ trees are balanced tree data structures commonly used for indexing in databases.

nodes.label: Hash indices: static and dynamic
nodes.title: Hash indices: static and dynamic
nodes.description: Hash indices: static and dynamic: Hash indices use hash functions to map keys to locations in a data structure for efficient retrieval.

nodes.label: Index creation in SQL
nodes.title: Index creation in SQL
nodes.description: Index creation in SQL: In SQL, indexes can be created using the CREATE INDEX statement.

nodes.label: Algorithms for query operators
nodes.title: Algorithms for query operators
nodes.description: Algorithms for query operators: Query operators include operations like selection, projection, joins, and sorting.

nodes.label: External Sorting
nodes.title: External Sorting
nodes.description: External Sorting: External sorting is a technique used to sort data that does not fit entirely in memory.

nodes.label: Selection
nodes.title: Selection
nodes.description: Selection: Selection is the process of filtering rows from a table based on a specified condition.

nodes.label: Projection;with and without duplicate elimination
nodes.title: Projection;with and without duplicate elimination
nodes.description: Projection;with and without duplicate elimination: Projection involves selecting specific columns from a table. Duplicate elimination removes duplicate rows from the result set.

nodes.label: Natural Joins: Nested loop, Sort-merge, Hash join
nodes.title: Natural Joins: Nested loop, Sort-merge, Hash join
nodes.description: Natural Joins: Nested loop, Sort-merge, Hash join: Natural joins combine rows from two tables based on matching values in specified columns.

nodes.label: Analysis of algorithm efficiency
nodes.title: Analysis of algorithm efficiency
nodes.description: Analysis of algorithm efficiency: Analysis of algorithm efficiency involves evaluating the performance of query processing algorithms in terms of time complexity, space complexity, and I/O costs.

nodes.label: Query transformations
nodes.title: Query transformations
nodes.description: Query transformations: Query transformations involve rewriting queries to optimize performance or simplify execution.

nodes.label: Query optimization
nodes.title: Query optimization
nodes.description: Query optimization: Query optimization is the process of choosing the most efficient query execution plan.

nodes.label: Access paths
nodes.title: Access paths
nodes.description: Access paths: Access paths determine how data is accessed during query execution, such as using indexes or performing full table scans.

nodes.label: Query plan construction
nodes.title: Query plan construction
nodes.description: Query plan construction: Query plan construction involves generating an execution plan for a query based on optimization decisions.

nodes.label: Selectivity estimation
nodes.title: Selectivity estimation
nodes.description: Selectivity estimation: Selectivity estimation involves estimating the fraction of rows that satisfy a given predicate in a query.

nodes.label: Index-only plans
nodes.title: Index-only plans
nodes.description: Index-only plans: Index-only plans leverage indexes to retrieve all necessary data for a query without accessing the underlying table.

nodes.label: Database tuning: Index selection
nodes.title: Database tuning: Index selection
nodes.description: Database tuning: Index selection: Database tuning involves selecting appropriate indexes to improve query performance based on workload characteristics and access patterns.

nodes.label: Impact of indices on query performance
nodes.title: Impact of indices on query performance
nodes.description: Impact of indices on query performance: Indices can significantly impact query performance by reducing the need for full table scans and improving data retrieval times.

nodes.label: DBMS Internals
nodes.title: DBMS Internals
nodes.description: DBMS Internals:

nodes.label: DB Buffer Management
nodes.title: DB Buffer Management
nodes.description: DB Buffer Management: DB buffer management involves managing the buffer pool in memory, where database pages are cached for quick access.

nodes.label: Transaction Processing
nodes.title: Transaction Processing
nodes.description: Transaction Processing: It involves grouping database operations into transactions and enforcing properties like atomicity, consistency, isolation, and durability (ACID).

nodes.label: Isolation Levels
nodes.title: Isolation Levels
nodes.description: Isolation Levels: Isolation levels define the degree to which transactions are isolated from each other.

nodes.label: ACID
nodes.title: ACID
nodes.description: ACID: ACID stands for Atomicity, Consistency, Isolation, and Durability, which are the four properties that ensure reliable transaction processing in a DBMS.

nodes.label: Serializability
nodes.title: Serializability
nodes.description: Serializability: Serializability is a property of a schedule of transactions that ensures its outcome is equivalent to a serial execution of the transactions.

nodes.label: Concurrency Control:
nodes.title: Concurrency Control:
nodes.description: Concurrency Control: : Concurrency control mechanisms manage access to shared resources in a multi-user environment to ensure consistency while allowing for concurrent transactions.

nodes.label: 2-Phase Locking
nodes.title: 2-Phase Locking
nodes.description: 2-Phase Locking: Two-phase locking is a concurrency control mechanism where transactions acquire locks in two phases: a growing phase (acquiring locks) and a shrinking phase (releasing locks).

nodes.label: Deadlocks handling strategies
nodes.title: Deadlocks handling strategies
nodes.description: Deadlocks handling strategies: Deadlocks occur when two or more transactions are waiting indefinitely for each other to release locks.

nodes.label: Recovery Manager
nodes.title: Recovery Manager
nodes.description: Recovery Manager: It includes mechanisms for logging changes to the database, checkpoints, and recovery algorithms like ARIES.

nodes.label: Relation with Buffer Manager
nodes.title: Relation with Buffer Manager
nodes.description: Relation with Buffer Manager: The buffer manager interacts closely with the recovery manager to ensure that database pages are properly written to disk and cached in memory.

nodes.label: NoSQL Systems
nodes.title: NoSQL Systems
nodes.description: NoSQL Systems:

nodes.label: Why NoSQL?
nodes.title: Why NoSQL?
nodes.description: Why NoSQL?: e.g. Impedance mismatch between Application [CRUD] and RDBMS

nodes.label: Key‐Value and Document data model
nodes.title: Key‐Value and Document data model
nodes.description: Key‐Value and Document data model :
